title: 115_s1363
content: The "Rural Broadband Deployment Streamlining Act" allows for the streamlined process of broadband facility location applications by the Department of the Interior and the Forest Service. The "Rural Broadband Deployment Streamlining Act" defines key terms such as broadband facility, covered land, department concerned, and organizational unit. The term "organizational unit" refers to specific offices within the Bureau of Land Management and the Forest Service. The term "Secretary concerned" refers to the Secretary of the Interior for public land and the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System land. Regulations must be established within one year of enactment. The Secretary concerned must issue regulations within one year to streamline the process for broadband facilities on covered land, ensure uniformity, and require applications to be considered competitively and neutrally. The regulations must include procedures for tracking applications. The regulations require identifying the number of applications received, approved, and denied, with reasons for denials. It also mandates minimum 5-year lease terms for broadband facilities on covered land, automatic renewal of authorizations, and fees. The regulations mandate minimum 5-year lease terms for broadband facilities on covered land, automatic renewal of authorizations, and fees based on the cost to the Department concerned. The Secretary shall consider how discrete reviews can be conducted simultaneously when considering applications. The regulations mandate minimum 5-year lease terms for broadband facilities on covered land, automatic renewal of authorizations, and fees based on the cost to the Department concerned. The Secretary shall consider how discrete reviews can be conducted simultaneously when considering applications. The streamlined process allows organizational units of the Department concerned to approve the location or modification of broadband facilities concurrently, eliminating overlapping requirements. The Secretary must communicate and ensure compliance with the regulations by the organizational units. SEC. 3. COMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES DEPLOYMENT ON FEDERAL PROPERTY. Section 6409(b) of the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 is amended to require executive agencies to grant or deny applications for easements or right-of-ways within 270 days and provide a clear explanation for any denials. Section 6409(b) of the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 now mandates executive agencies to grant or deny applications for easements or right-of-ways within 270 days. If the agency fails to meet this deadline, the application is deemed granted. The agency must still comply with environmental laws and designate a point of contact upon receiving an application. Executive agencies must designate a point of contact with the applicant for applications under subparagraph (A). SEC. 4. GAO REPORT. The National Broadband Map, established under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, is evaluated by the Comptroller General of the United States in a report to Congress. The report assesses the accuracy, completeness, and reliability of broadband data collected by the Federal Communications Commission, including data sources and potential alternative sources. It also examines the distribution of Federal grants or loans for broadband by authorized entities. The Federal Communications Commission relies on data from the National Broadband Map to award grants or loans for broadband projects and determine funding in areas already served by private providers. The report evaluates the accuracy of the data, challenges to its information, and the need for additional data collection for the map. The Federal Communications Commission evaluates the accuracy of data for the National Broadband Map and considers collecting data from additional commercial sources.
